awd_titl_txt: Improving Sustainability of Atomic Layer Deposition: a Hierarchical Systems Approach
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project is to study and improve the sustainability performance of Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) through a hierarchical systems approach. ALD is a key enabling nanotechnology that has been adopted in the semiconductor manufacturing industry. Currently ALD is under rapid development for a broad array of industrial applications including solar cells, fuel cells, lithium-ion batteries, medical devices, sensors, etc. However, ALD has significant sustainability issues due to its heavy use of toxic chemicals, potential generation of nano-particle emissions, and intensive use of energy. The goal of this project is to research mathematical models and analytical tools for reducing the environmental impact and economic costs of ALD nano-manufacturing for industrial-scale applications. This project will be carried out in a systematic manner that integrates both mathematical modeling and experimental investigations. Specific research goals of this project are: (1) mathematical modeling and experimental investigations of ALD process emissions (2) thermodynamic flows and energy modeling of ALD nano-manufacturing system (3) sustainable scale-up of ALD nanotechnology for industrial productions. 

If successful, the models and results developed in this study will allow ALD and associated industries to address the long-term environmental and societal implications of ALD nanotechnology.  The models and results can also be used in sustainable management and improvement of similar bottom-up nanotechnologies. The research results of this project will be broadly disseminated through academic journals, professional conferences, and internet media.  As a result, this research will improve our understanding of the potential environmental impacts of ALD nano-manufacturing and assist in development of a sustainable infrastructure for ALD productions in various industrial sectors.

por.por_cntn:
Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD), as a key enabling nanotechnology, has been adopted in industrial-scale semiconductor manufacturing and is under rapid development for a broad array of industrial applications including solar cells, fuel cells, lithium-ion batteries, medical devices, sensors, etc. However, ALD has significant sustainability issues in such aspects as heavy wastes of toxic chemicals, generation of nano-particle emissions, high energy use, etc. This project has been conducted to investigate and improve the sustainability of ALD nano-manufacturing during its design-to-manufacturing cycle using a hierarchical system approach. Focuses of this study are on development of mathematical models and tools for reducing the environmental impact and economic costs of ALD nano-manufacturing for industrial-scale applications. This project has been carried out in a systematic manner that integrates both mathematical modeling and experimental investigations. Specific research activities of this project include: (1) development of mathematical models and conducting experimental investigations on environmental emissions from ALD processes (2) conducting thermodynamic flows and energy modeling of ALD nano-manufacturing system (3) study the scale-up potential of ALD nanotechnology for industrial productions. The models and results developed in this study are useful for ALD and associated industries in addressing the long-term environmental and societal implications of ALD nanotechnology, and can also be used in sustainable management and improvement of similar bottom-up nanotechnologies.

Intellectual Merits: Major innovations of the project include the development of process-based mathematical models validated through experimentation for understanding and improving the sustainability performance of ALD nano-manufacturing process.  In this research, fundamental mechanisms of ALD process are numerically modeled through Lattice Boltzmann method,  density functional theory, and atomic-level calculations on the effects of such ALD process parameters including process temperature, pulse time, purge time, and carrier gas flow rate on ALD film deposition rate, process emissions and wastes. Our simulations reveal that the depositions of nano-thin-films in ALD are in essence the chemisorption of the gaseous species and the conversion of surface species. Methane emissions are positively proportional to the film deposition process. The research project shows that process temperature fundamentally affects the ALD chemical process by changing the energy states of the surface species. Pulse time is directly related to the precursor dosage. Purge time influences the ALD process by changing the gas-surface interaction time, and a higher carrier gas flow rate can alter the ALD flow field by accelerating the convective heat and mass transfer in ALD process. The experimental study on nano-particle emissions from the ALD process reveals that net peak emissions are between 1000 and 10000 particles per cubic centimeter and net total emissions of 25 cycles are in the range of 600000 and 2500000 particles. Most particles are determined with diameter smaller than 100 nm. It is also found the ALD purging time has significant impacts on the nano-particle emission concentrations but no effect on the particle size distribution. In this research, we have developed thermodynamic energy flow models for ALD process and studied the specific energy consumption (SEC) of ALD technology in terms of the energy consumption per ALD cycle, and found that the SEC can be reduced significantly with the optimization of ALD process parameters. Finally, we have investigated the scale-up potential of ALD technology in terms of batch-size production and roll-to-roll production. It is found that ALD process temperature and purge time show great influence on the film growth rate during ALD batch-size production, but no significant effect among the refractive indices of deposited films. For the roll-to-roll ALD production, it is found that increasing the gap size to 2 mm can result in less precursor intermixture, but generates slightly lower saturated deposition rate in a much shorter critical dosing time. Wafer temperature is shown as a significant factor in both flow and surface deposition processes. Higher temperature can accelerates the diffusive mass transport, which largely contributes to the precursor intermixing. On the other hand, higher temperature increases film deposition rate.

Broader Impacts: ALD plays a critical role in nano-manufacturing industry for miniaturizing nano-devices, modifying surface properties, developing novel nano-structures, etc. ALD is promising for large-scale applications in a broad array of industrial sectors. The research results of this project has been developed into course modules and integrated into three courses for both undergraduate student and graduate student education at the University of Wisconsin, Milwaukee. The course module has also been made available to the public through the NSF SMART platform. The research results have been broadly disseminated to the research community of interests, with 13 journal papers published, and 4 conference presentations being delivered. In this research, there were two postdoc researchers, three Ph.D. students and three undergraduate students involved and received training on the proposed research topics. International collaborations with researchers in Australia and China have also been successfully pursued.
